meta.videoTitle: How to Prevent & Treat Colds & Flu

proposition: The flu virus is a type of virus.
The flu virus is similar to the cold virus.
The flu virus comes in different variations known as serotypes.
There are three main categories of flu viruses: type A, type B, and type C.
The variations of flu viruses are based on the different proteins expressed on their surface.
The Spanish Flu was a devastating pandemic that occurred between 1918 and 1920.
The Spanish Flu was caused by a type A H1N1 virus.
The common flu viruses fall under the category of type A.
Type A flu viruses are responsible for causing seasonal flu outbreaks.
The transmission of the flu virus primarily occurs through human-to-human contact.
The flu virus can be contracted by being exposed to respiratory droplets from an infected person's sneeze or cough.
The flu virus can be transmitted by touching surfaces contaminated with the virus and then touching the face.
This allows the flu virus to enter the body through mucous membranes.
The flu virus can only survive on surfaces for about two hours.
Direct contact with an infected individual is the primary mode of transmission of the flu virus.
Vaccines are developed each year to combat the spread of the flu virus.
Vaccines are commonly known as flu shots.
Flu shots target specific strains of the flu virus.
The effectiveness of the flu shot varies depending on the match between the vaccine and the circulating flu strains.
Studies have shown that getting the flu shot can reduce the risk of contracting the prevalent flu strain by 40% to 60% in a given season.
Even if an individual still gets the flu after receiving the vaccine, the symptoms may be less severe.
The decision to get a flu shot is a personal one.
The decision to get a flu shot depends on factors such as individual health status and level of exposure to potential sources of the virus.
Some people opt not to get vaccinated due to lower risk factors or personal preferences.
Others may choose to get vaccinated to protect themselves.
Others may choose to get vaccinated to protect vulnerable individuals around them.
Such vulnerable individuals include those who are immunocompromised.
Such vulnerable individuals include those in high-risk environments like schools or healthcare settings.
Getting the flu shot is a preventative measure.
The flu shot can help reduce the risk of flu infection.
The flu shot can help reduce the severity of flu infection.
Each individual should consider their own circumstances.
Each individual should consult with healthcare professionals.
Consulting with healthcare professionals can help make an informed decision.
The decision about whether getting the flu shot is the right choice should be informed.
